articles.title: EC: The decisions on Bulgaria’s admission to the euro area have already been adopted and remain in force
articles.summary: Bulgaria will be the 21st member of the eurozone from January 1, 2026 – 19 years after the country’s accession to the European Union
articles.content:
Bulgaria will be the 21st member of the eurozone from January 1, 2026 – 19 years after the country’s accession to the European Union

BRUSSELS – The decisions on the admission of Bulgaria to the eurozone have already been adopted and remain in force. This was stated by a spokesperson of the European Commission (EC) at a press conference in response to a question whether it is possible for a change to occur by January 1 next year because of the political situation in Bulgaria.

Asked whether there is a “technical possibility” for Bulgaria not to enter the eurozone from the beginning of next year, or to leave after it has once been admitted, the spokesperson explained that the answer to this question is very clear. There are certain requirements (for joining the eurozone) and Bulgaria has met them, he said. All the relevant decisions were taken and it is envisaged that from January 1 Bulgaria will introduce the euro, the spokesperson summed up.

Bulgaria will be the 21st member of the eurozone from January 1, 2026 – 19 years after the country’s accession to the European Union. The Council of the EU voted unanimously on July 8, 2025 on the final decisions related to the adoption of the euro in the country. With this, the procedure was completed, after earlier the same day the European Parliament also approved by a large majority the report on the introduction of the single European currency by Bulgaria.

From December 1 the sale of starter kits with Bulgarian euro coins for citizens and businesses began in the country.

The EC’s position came against the background of events in the country in recent weeks. After a series of anti-government protests, on December 11 the Bulgarian government with Prime Minister Rossen Zhelyazkov resigned, and on the next day it was voted on by the National Assembly.

On the same day, the party “Vazrazhdane”, which during the year organized several protests against Bulgaria’s accession to the eurozone, announced its intention to propose that parliament adopt a decision obliging the Council of Ministers to request a one-year postponement of the introduction of the euro. However, the leader of the party Kostadin Kostadinov stated that he does not expect the proposal to receive support from the other parliamentary forces. (12.12.2025)
articles.reasoning: Bulgaria's confirmed accession to the eurozone represents a significant economic integration milestone with broad implications for the country's economy and the European Union, offering measurable benefits to the public and regional stability. The article provides clear context and details about the decision and its timeline, despite some political challenges.
articles.personality_title: Bulgaria to join the eurozone on January 1, 2026, confirming long-planned economic step
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Bulgaria joined the European Union 19 years ago, in 2007. Since then, it has worked toward adopting the euro, the common currency used by many EU countries. Joining the eurozone means Bulgaria will use the euro instead of its own currency.

**What happened** – The European Commission confirmed that Bulgaria will officially join the eurozone on January 1, 2026. This decision was agreed on by the Council of the EU and approved by the European Parliament in July 2025. Despite recent political protests and the resignation of Bulgaria’s government in December 2025, the plan to adopt the euro is moving forward. Starting December 1, Bulgarians could buy starter kits of euro coins to prepare for the change.

**Impact** – Becoming the 21st member of the eurozone means Bulgaria’s economy will be more closely connected to other EU countries that use the euro. This can make trade, travel, and business easier and more predictable. It also shows Bulgaria met all the important rules and conditions needed to join, which is a strong sign of economic progress.

**What's next step** – Bulgaria will begin using the euro as its official currency starting January 1, 2026. Businesses and citizens will adapt to the new currency, and the government will continue working to support this transition smoothly. Political debates might continue, but the euro adoption is set to proceed as planned.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Bulgaria is set to adopt the euro in early 2026, marking a major step in its economic integration with Europe despite recent political challenges.
articles.personality_title_fr: La Bulgarie rejoindra la zone euro le 1er janvier 2026, confirmant une étape économique importante
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La Bulgarie a rejoint l’Union européenne il y a 19 ans, en 2007. Depuis, elle travaille à adopter l’euro, la monnaie commune utilisée par de nombreux pays de l’UE. Rejoindre la zone euro signifie que la Bulgarie utilisera l’euro au lieu de sa propre monnaie.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – La Commission européenne a confirmé que la Bulgarie rejoindra officiellement la zone euro le 1er janvier 2026. Cette décision a été approuvée par le Conseil de l’UE et le Parlement européen en juillet 2025. Malgré des manifestations politiques récentes et la démission du gouvernement bulgare en décembre 2025, le plan d’adoption de l’euro avance. Dès le 1er décembre, les Bulgares pouvaient acheter des kits de départ avec des pièces en euro pour se préparer au changement.

**Impact** – Devenir le 21e membre de la zone euro signifie que l’économie bulgare sera plus étroitement liée à celle des autres pays de l’UE utilisant l’euro. Cela peut faciliter le commerce, les voyages et les affaires. Cela montre aussi que la Bulgarie a rempli toutes les conditions nécessaires, signe de progrès économique.

**Prochaine étape** – La Bulgarie commencera à utiliser l’euro comme monnaie officielle à partir du 1er janvier 2026. Les entreprises et les citoyens devront s’adapter à la nouvelle monnaie, et le gouvernement continuera à soutenir cette transition. Les débats politiques pourraient continuer, mais l’adoption de l’euro est prévue comme prévu.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – La Bulgarie adoptera l’euro début 2026, marquant une étape majeure dans son intégration économique en Europe malgré des défis politiques récents.
articles.personality_title_es: Bulgaria se unirá a la zona euro el 1 de enero de 2026, confirmando un paso económico importante
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Bulgaria se unió a la Unión Europea hace 19 años, en 2007. Desde entonces, ha trabajado para adoptar el euro, la moneda común usada por muchos países de la UE. Entrar en la zona euro significa que Bulgaria usará el euro en lugar de su propia moneda.

**Qué pasó** – La Comisión Europea confirmó que Bulgaria se unirá oficialmente a la zona euro el 1 de enero de 2026. Esta decisión fue aprobada por el Consejo de la UE y el Parlamento Europeo en julio de 2025. A pesar de protestas políticas recientes y la renuncia del gobierno búlgaro en diciembre de 2025, el plan para adoptar el euro sigue adelante. Desde el 1 de diciembre, los búlgaros pueden comprar kits iniciales con monedas en euro para prepararse.

**Impacto** – Convertirse en el miembro número 21 de la zona euro significa que la economía de Bulgaria estará más conectada con otros países de la UE que usan el euro. Esto puede facilitar el comercio, los viajes y los negocios. También muestra que Bulgaria cumplió con todas las reglas necesarias, lo que es una señal de progreso económico.

**Próximo paso** – Bulgaria comenzará a usar el euro como moneda oficial a partir del 1 de enero de 2026. Las empresas y ciudadanos deberán adaptarse a la nueva moneda, y el gobierno continuará apoyando esta transición. Puede que continúen los debates políticos, pero la adopción del euro seguirá según lo planeado.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Bulgaria adoptará el euro a principios de 2026, marcando un paso importante en su integración económica con Europa a pesar de desafíos políticos recientes.

articles.title: Yet a fourth amendment to the Slovenian recovery plan
articles.summary: At their last meeting, the EU finance ministers supported the fourth, and according to the government’s announcements the final, amendment to Slovenia’s recovery and resilience plan, and in terms of the amount of funds drawn so far, Slovenia is among the more successful EU member states.
articles.content:
At their last meeting, the EU finance ministers supported the fourth, and according to the government’s announcements the final, amendment to Slovenia’s recovery and resilience plan, and in terms of the amount of funds drawn so far, Slovenia is among the more successful EU member states.

Brussels/Ljubljana – EU finance ministers on Friday approved the fourth amendment to Slovenia’s recovery and resilience plan. Under the amendment, Slovenia will have a total of slightly fewer grants and loans, namely 2.14 billion euros, and there will also be fewer milestones and targets that will need to be met. This is expected to be the last major change to the plan, which expires at the end of August 2026.

The government had already approved the fourth amendment to the plan in October. It reduced the volume of available loans by 87 million euros to 526 million euros, while keeping the volume of grants at 1.61 billion. In total, Slovenia will have around 2.14 billion euros in grants and loans at its disposal. Under the new arrangement, there are to be 181 milestones and targets instead of the 200 previously envisaged.

If the newly approved amendment to the recovery plan is taken into account, Slovenia has so far drawn around 72 percent of all available funds, which places it among the more successful EU member states in terms of absorption. From the mechanism, it has so far received a total of 1.54 billion euros, with which the country has supported around 1,360 projects in various fields with a total value of 1.14 billion euros. (12 December)
articles.reasoning: The article reports on the EU finance ministers approving the final amendment to Slovenia's recovery and resilience plan, highlighting Slovenia's successful absorption of substantial EU funds to support numerous projects. This reflects meaningful economic recovery and development benefiting a broad population, with clear context and measurable impact.
articles.personality_title: EU approves final update to Slovenia’s recovery plan, boosting progress on projects
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – After the COVID-19 pandemic, the European Union created recovery and resilience plans to help member countries rebuild their economies. These plans include funding and goals for projects that support growth and development.

**What happened** – On December 12, EU finance ministers agreed on the fourth and likely final change to Slovenia’s recovery and resilience plan. This update slightly reduced the total money available to Slovenia to 2.14 billion euros and lowered the number of goals from 200 to 181. Slovenia’s government had already accepted these changes in October.

**Impact** – Slovenia has used about 72% of its available funds, making it one of the top countries in the EU for quickly accessing this support. So far, the country has received 1.54 billion euros and helped around 1,360 projects in different areas, with a combined value of 1.14 billion euros. This shows Slovenia is effectively using EU funds to support many projects that help the country grow.

**What's next step** – The recovery plan will continue until August 2026. Slovenia will work on meeting the remaining goals and using the rest of its funds to complete ongoing projects and start new ones.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The EU’s approval of Slovenia’s final recovery plan update marks strong progress in funding and completing hundreds of projects to rebuild the country’s economy.
articles.personality_title_fr: L’UE approuve la dernière mise à jour du plan de relance slovène, accélérant les projets
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Après la pandémie de COVID-19, l’Union européenne a créé des plans de relance pour aider les pays membres à reconstruire leurs économies. Ces plans comprennent des financements et des objectifs pour des projets favorisant la croissance et le développement.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le 12 décembre, les ministres des finances de l’UE ont accepté la quatrième et probablement dernière modification du plan de relance slovène. Cette mise à jour réduit légèrement le montant total disponible pour la Slovénie, à 2,14 milliards d’euros, et diminue le nombre d’objectifs de 200 à 181. Le gouvernement slovène avait déjà approuvé ces changements en octobre.

**Impact** – La Slovénie a utilisé environ 72 % de ses fonds disponibles, ce qui en fait l’un des pays de l’UE ayant le mieux accédé à ce soutien. Jusqu’à présent, le pays a reçu 1,54 milliard d’euros et soutenu environ 1 360 projets dans différents domaines, pour une valeur totale de 1,14 milliard d’euros. Cela montre que la Slovénie utilise efficacement les fonds européens pour soutenir de nombreux projets qui aident à la croissance.

**Prochaine étape** – Le plan de relance se poursuivra jusqu’en août 2026. La Slovénie travaillera à atteindre les objectifs restants et à utiliser le reste des fonds pour achever les projets en cours et en lancer de nouveaux.

**Résumé en une phrase** – L’approbation par l’UE de la dernière mise à jour du plan de relance slovène marque un fort progrès dans le financement et la réalisation de centaines de projets pour reconstruire l’économie du pays.
articles.personality_title_es: La UE aprueba la última actualización del plan de recuperación de Eslovenia, impulsando proyectos
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Después de la pandemia de COVID-19, la Unión Europea creó planes de recuperación para ayudar a los países miembros a reconstruir sus economías. Estos planes incluyen fondos y metas para proyectos que apoyan el crecimiento y desarrollo.

**Qué sucedió** – El 12 de diciembre, los ministros de finanzas de la UE aprobaron la cuarta y probablemente última modificación del plan de recuperación y resiliencia de Eslovenia. Esta actualización redujo ligeramente el dinero total disponible a 2,14 mil millones de euros y bajó las metas de 200 a 181. El gobierno esloveno ya había aceptado estos cambios en octubre.

**Impacto** – Eslovenia ha utilizado alrededor del 72 % de sus fondos disponibles, situándose entre los países de la UE que más rápido acceden a este apoyo. Hasta ahora, el país ha recibido 1,54 mil millones de euros y ha apoyado cerca de 1.360 proyectos en diferentes áreas, con un valor total de 1,14 mil millones de euros. Esto muestra que Eslovenia usa bien los fondos para apoyar muchos proyectos que ayudan a crecer al país.

**Próximo paso** – El plan de recuperación seguirá hasta agosto de 2026. Eslovenia trabajará para cumplir las metas restantes y usar el resto de los fondos para terminar proyectos en marcha y comenzar nuevos.

**Resumen en una frase** – La aprobación por parte de la UE de la última actualización del plan de recuperación de Eslovenia destaca un progreso sólido en financiar y completar cientos de proyectos para reconstruir la economía del país.
